title: Chinese Government donates anti-epidemic supplies to the Bahamas in July 2020
description: On July 31, 2020, the Chinese Government donated anti-epidemic supplies to the Bahamas Government. Huang Qinguo, Chinese Ambassador to the Bahamas met with the newly appointed Hon. Renward Wells, Minister of Health of the Bahamas, and jointly attended the handover ceremony of the supplies. The types and the monetary value of the donation are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates anti-epidemic supplies to the Bahamas in July 2020

# Description
On July 31, 2020, the Chinese Government donated anti-epidemic supplies to the Bahamas Government. Huang Qinguo, Chinese Ambassador to the Bahamas met with the newly appointed Hon. Renward Wells, Minister of Health of the Bahamas, and jointly attended the handover ceremony of the supplies. The types and the monetary value of the donation are unknown.
justification: Project is a donation of medical supplies with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic supplies donation, healthcare sector focus

title: China Eximbank contributes to $1.77 billion syndicated loan for 1320 (2 x 600) MW Patuakhali Coal-Fired Thermal Power Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#56005, #52748, #38245, #56357, #56547, and #96157)
description: On December 24, 2020, China Eximbank and Bank of China signed a $1.77 billion syndicated loan (facility) agreement with RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd. (RNPL) — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) [50% ownership take] and NORINCO International Cooperation Limited [50% ownership stake] that was legally incorporated in December 2017 — for the 1320 (2 x 600) MW Patuakhali Coal-Fired Thermal Power Plant Construction Project. The loan carries a 2.9% interest rate and a 14-year maturity. The Ministry of Finance of Bangladesh issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan on March 8, 2021.   The first loan disbursement took place on September 26, 2021. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance an EPC contract that it signed with a consortium consisting of Tianjin Electric Power Construction Co. Ltd., China Huadian Engineering Co. Ltd, and China Wanbao Engineering Corporation (TEPC-CHEC-CWEC) on March 6, 2019. The total cost of the project is approximately $2.54 billion and it is being financed according to a 70:30 debt-to-equity ratio.   The purpose of the project is to construct a thermal power plant with two 660MW coal-fired units (‘Unit 1’ and ‘Unit 2’) in Kalapara within Patuakhali District. The project site is located on the western bank of the Rabnabad River, in the vicinity of the Payra Port, 210km away from Dhaka and 160km away from Chittagong. Each 660MW power generation unit will be equipped with an ultra-supercritical boiler along with a high-efficiency steam turbine and a generator. The plant will be equipped with low nitrogen oxide (Nox) burner, electrostatic precipitators (ESP), and a flue gas desulphurisation (FGD) system to control emissions. Other components of the project will include a closed-cycle cooling system, 275m-high flue stacks, and a 400kV gas-insulated substation (GIS). The plant will source water from the Rabnabad River for cooling. The Patuakhali power plant is estimated to consume 4.48 million tonnes (Mt) of coal a year, which will be imported from Indonesia and Australia. Other infrastructure for the Patuakhali power project will include a coal jetty, coal handling and storage facilities, and access roads for transporting material and equipment. The project site will also house a water treatment facility and a warehouse building. The construction works are being facilitated by a concrete batching plant and a temporary project office. The electricity generated by the Patuakhali coal-fired power plant will be evacuated into the national grid of Bangladesh through a 400kV power transmission line. The power plant will process 12273 tons of coal per day and sell power to the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB). Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPBD) will offtake the entire electricity output of the plant, under a power purchase agreement (PPA) that it signed with RNPL in February 2019.  The power plant is expected to displace 350 families, so RPCL plans to set up a village with schools, shops, community centers, and mosques to accommodate them.   TEPC-CHEC-CWEC is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Central Southern China Electric Power Design Institute (CSEPDI) of China Power Engineering Consulting Group Corporation was also involved in the design of the project. RNPL issued a notice to proceed (NTP) to the EPC contractor (TEPC-CHEC-CWEC) on August 31, 2019. Construction began on September 1, 2019. As of October 2022, the project had achieved a 61.19% completion rate. The power plant’s first 660MW unit (Unit 1) was originally expected to come online by February 2023, followed by the commissioning of the second 660MW unit (Unit 2) in August 2023.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title  孟加拉博杜阿卡利1320MW燃煤电站项目建设 or Patuakhali 2台66万千瓦燃煤电站业主工程师咨询服务项目. 2. AidData has coded this transaction as a collateralized loan because Agrani Bank was selected as the security agent (i.e. collateral agent) for the loan. When lenders take collateral as security for their loans, a collateral/security agent is often appointed to enforce rights against the collateral in the event of the borrower’s default under the loan. 3. As of February 2023, this government-guaranteed BoC/CEXIM loan was not captured in the China’s Global Energy Finance (CGEF) Database or China's Overseas Development Finance (CODF) Datbase published by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center.4. There are three different power plants being constructed in the Patuakhali region of Bangladesh. Each one of these projects is funded partially via joint ventures between Chinese and Bangladeshi state-owned enterprises and partially via China Eximbank loans. Two of the coal-fired plants will contain two 660MW generators, with the third project involves two phases, both of which have two 660MW generators. The joint venture partners have clarified that these plants are near each other, but they are distinct plants supporting a region-wide electrification campaign. These projects include: (i) Bangladesh’s Northwest Power Generation Company Ltd. and China National Machinery Import & Export Corporation, which established the Bangladesh-China Power Company Ltd. (BCPCL) joint venture in October 2014 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) Ultra Supercritical Coal Based Thermal Power Plant Project (Phase 2). The joint venture is captured in Project ID #56005. China Eximbank is funding phase one (units 1 and 2) of this project (see Project ID#52748). China Eximbank financing for phase two (units 3 and 4) is currently unspecified, with the most recent details record in Project ID#38245.(ii) Bangladesh’s Ashuganj Power Station Company Ltd. (APSCL) and China’s China Energy Engineering Corporation Ltd. (CEEC) established a joint venture in July 2017 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of Patuakhali 1320MW (2 x 660MW) Coal-Fired Power Plant (Ashuganj/ APSCL). The joint venture is captured in Project ID#56547. CEEC will solicit a loan from the China Eximbank for the debt portion of the project. China Eximbank financing for this project is currently not captured in a stand-alone Project ID#.(iii) Bangladesh’s Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) and China’s NORINCO, which established a joint venture in November 2017 to oversee the financing, design, and construction of 1320MW (2 x 660MW) MW Patuakhali Coal Fired Thermal Power Plant. The joint venture is captured in Project ID#56357.5. The specific monetary contributions of Bank of China and China Eximbank to the loan syndicate are unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes equal contributions ($885,000,000) by the two members of the syndicate.  Project ID#56402 captures China Eximbank's estimated contribution and Project ID#96157 captures Bank of China's estimated contribution.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank contributes to $1.77 billion syndicated loan for 1320 (2 x 600) MW Patuakhali Coal-Fired Thermal Power Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#56005, #52748, #38245, #56357, #56547, and #96157)

# Description
On December 24, 2020, China Eximbank and Bank of China signed a $1.77 billion syndicated loan (facility) agreement with RPCL-NORINCO Intl. Power Ltd. (RNPL) — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of Rural Power Company Ltd. (RPCL) [50% ownership take] and NORINCO International Cooperation Limited [50% ownership stake] that was legally incorporated in December 2017 — for the 1320 (2 x 600) MW Patuakhali Coal-Fired Thermal Power Plant Construction Project. The loan carries a 2.9% interest rate and a 14-year maturity. The Ministry of Finance of Bangladesh issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan on March 8, 2021.   The first loan disbursement took place on September 26, 2021. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance an EPC contract that it signed with a consortium consisting of Tianjin Electric Power Construction Co. Ltd., China Huadian Engineering Co. Ltd, and China Wanbao Engineering Corporation (TEPC-CHEC-CWEC) on March 6, 2019. The total cost of the project is approximately $2.54 billion and it is being financed according to a 70:30 debt-to-equity ratio.   The purpose of the project is to construct a thermal power plant with two 660MW coal-fired units (‘Unit 1’ and ‘Unit 2’) in Kalapara within Patuakhali District. The project site is located on the western bank of the Rabnabad River, in the vicinity of the Payra Port, 210km away from Dhaka and 160km away from Chittagong. Each 660MW power generation unit will be equipped with an ultra-supercritical boiler along with a high-efficiency steam turbine and a generator. Other components of the project will include a closed-cycle cooling system, 275m-high flue stacks, and a 400kV gas-insulated substation (GIS). The plant will source water from the Rabnabad River for cooling. The Patuakhali power plant is estimated to consume 4.48 million tonnes (Mt) of coal a year, which will be imported from Indonesia and Australia. Other infrastructure for the Patuakhali power project will include a coal jetty, coal handling and storage facilities, and access roads for transporting material and equipment. Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPBD) will offtake the entire electricity output of the plant, under a power purchase agreement (PPA) that it signed with RNPL in February 2019.  The power plant is expected to displace 350 families, so RPCL plans to set up a village with schools, shops, community centers, and mosques to accommodate them.   TEPC-CHEC-CWEC is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Central Southern China Electric Power Design Institute (CSEPDI) of China Power Engineering Consulting Group Corporation was also involved in the design of the project. RNPL issued a notice to proceed (NTP) to the EPC contractor (TEPC-CHEC-CWEC) on August 31, 2019. Construction began on September 1, 2019. As of October 2022, the project had achieved a 61.19% completion rate. The power plant’s first 660MW unit (Unit 1) was originally expected to come online by February 2023, followed by the commissioning of the second 660MW unit (Unit 2) in August 2023.
justification: Primary purpose is coal-fired power generation, despite some emission control measures
evidence: 1320MW coal-fired power plant, 4.48 million tonnes of coal consumption annually, coal import infrastructure

title: China Eximbank provides $686.5 million preferential buyer’s credit for Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under PGCB (Linked to Project ID#54399)
description: In November 2016, the Government of Bangladesh’s National Economic Commission Executive Committee (ECNEC) approved the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under the Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB). Then, On August 11, 2017, China Eximbank reportedly expressed interest in financing the project and invited Bangladesh’s Ministry of Finance to submit a loan application. On June 7, 2020, China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh signed two loan agreements for the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under PGCB: an RMB 1,930,000,000 ($279.71 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement and a $686.571 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement. The GCL, which is captured via Project ID#54399, carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 2% interest rate, and a 0.2% commitment fee. The PBC, which is captured via Project ID#92465, carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, a 3% interest rate, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee. The PBC and GCL proceeds were to be used by the borrower to finance a $1,141,200,116.04 commercial (EPC) contract between PGCB and a consortium consisting of CCC Engineering Ltd, Jiangsu ETERN Co Ltd, and Fujian Electric Power Company, which was signed on October 10, 2016. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 51.8% (RMB 1,000,101,000 out of RMB 1,930,000,000) as of June 30, 2021 but the PBC had disbursed as of June 30, 2021. The borrower had not made any repayments under the GCL or PBC as of June 30, 2021.  The purpose of the project is to construct 989.7 kilometers of new transmission lines and install 41 new substations in Dhaka and Mymensingh. More specifically, the project involves the following components:  (a) 400 kV Kaliakoir-Mymensingh transmission line: 100km  (b) 230 kV transmission line: 330.20 km  (c) 132 kV transmission line: 334.50km  (d) Conductor up gradation of existing 132 kV transmission line: 225 km  (e) 400/132 kV new Substation: 01 Nos (1x 650 MVA) (f) Construction of new 230/132 kV substations: 12 nos. (total 9200 MVA)  (g) Capacity up gradation of existing 230/132 kV substations: 7 nos. (3035 MVA)  (h) Construction of new 132/33 kV substations: 28 nos. (7404 MVA)  (i) Capacity up gradation of existing 132/33 kV substations: 28 nos.(8044 MVA)  (j) Extension of Existing 400 kV Substation: 1 nos  (k) Extension of Existing 230 kV Substation: 3 nos (l) Extension of Existing 132 kV Substation: 14 nos  (m) Renovation of existing substations: 05 Nos.  (n) To construct new Specialized Engineering Facilities: 7 nos.  Components (a) and (b) involve 1. Construction of Kaliakoir - Shambhuganj (Mymensingh) 400 kV double circuit line: 100 km 2. Construction of Barapukuria (New) - Rangpur Substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line: 40km 3. Construction of Kaliakoir - Tangail Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 40km 4. Construction of Khulna (S) substation - Khulna (Central) 230 kV substation (proposed) double circuit line: 0.2 km 5. Construction of Mymensingh substation (proposed)- Phulpur AIS substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 35 km 6. Construction of Barisal(N) - Patuakhali 230kV double circuit line: 55km 7. Construction of Bibiyana 230 kV substation - Sylhet (S) 230 kV GIS substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 40km 8. Construction of Sylhet(S) Substation (proposed) - Sylhet (E) Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 10 km 9. Construction of Sylhet (Kumargaon) - Sylhet (S) 230 kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 16 km 10. Construction of Sylhet (Kumargaon) - Sylhet (N) substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line (Initially to be charged at 132kV): 7km 11. Construction of Bhulta - Jalshiri 230kV double circuit line: 12km (Initially to be charged at 132kV). 12. Construction of Sylhet (E) substation (proposed) - Sylhet (N) substation (proposed) 230 kV double circuit line: 16km 13. Construction of Kaliakoir - Kabirpur Substation (proposed) 230kV double circuit line: 15km 14. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Ishurdi - Ghorasal 230 kV double circuit line at new Dhamrai substation: 1km 15. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Comilla (N) - Meghnaghat 230 kV double circuit line at new Gazaria substation: 1km 16. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Bheramara HVDC - Khulna (S) 230kV Line at Jessore: 8 km 17. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Bibiyana - Fenchuganj 230 kV double circuit line at new Bibiyana substation: 1km 18. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Barapukuria - Bogra 230 kV double circuit line at new Barapukuria (N) substation: 10km 19. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Ghorasal - Rampura 230 kV double circuit line at new Madhobdi substation: 1km 20. Construction of four circuit Line In Line Out from Barapukuria - Bogra 230 kV double circuit line at new Palashbari substation: 22 km.    Components (e) an and (f) involve 1. Construction of 400/132/33 kV AIS Substation with 2x225/325 MVA & 4x20 MVA transformer at Shambhuganj (Mymensingh) 2. Construction of 230 kV AIS Switching station at Barapukuria(N) 3. Construction of 230/132/33 kV GIS Substation with 2x150 MVA & 2x50/75 MVA transformers at Bibiyana 4. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA & 3x80/120 MVA transformer at Khulna Central 5. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS substation with 2x300/450 MVA & 3x80/120 MVA transformer including 50 MVAR Capacitor Bank at 33kV side at Madhobdi 6. Construction of 230/132/33kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA & 1x50/75 MVA transformer including 50 MVAR Capacitor Bank at 33kV side at Palashbari 7. Construction of 230/132/33 kV GIS Substation with 2x300/450 MVA & 2x80/120 MVA transformer at Gazaria 8. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer atDhamrai 9. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Jessore 10. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Rangpur 11. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 3x300/450 MVA transformer at Kabirpur 12. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Tangail 13. Construction of 230/132 kV GIS Substation with 2x250/350 MVA transformer at Sylhet (S).  CCC Engineering Ltd, Jiangsu ETERN Co Ltd, and Fujian Electric Power Company are the EPC contractors responsible for implementation. Project implementation officially commenced on February 16, 2021. As of August 2021, the project had achieved an 18.9% completion rate. By December 2021, land for 72 of the 92 power substations supported by the project had been handed over to the CCCE-ETERN-FEPEC consortium and soil testing was underway for another 17 substations. The project was originally scheduled for completion in June 2024. However, it is running behind schedule due to the Covid-19 pandemic and other factors. The CCCE-ETERN-FEPEC Consortium was unable to provide the necessary manpower. PGCB was also asked to provide 370 staff members to support the implementation project. It provided only 60 — much lower than the requirement. Another obstacle has been the lack of funds for compensation to the local people who are being affected by the implementation of the project. Upon completion, the project is expected to add 10,000 MW power transmission capacity to the PGCB network.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Power Grid Network Strengthening Project under Power Grid Company of Bangladesh (PGCB). The Chinese project title is 孟加拉国家电网公司电网升级改造项目 or 孟加拉国家电网公司电网升级改造项目 or 孟加拉国家电网升级改造交钥匙工程. 2. This project should not be confused with the Enhancement and Strengthening of Power Network in Eastern Region Project, which is managed by PGCB and supported by the World Bank. 3. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for the GCL is L1120200607A. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for the PBC is B1120200607A. 4. The EPC consortium responsible for this project is known as the CCCE-Jiangsu ETERN-FEPEC consortium. Fujian Electric Power Company is a subsidiary of PowerChina.

justification: The project focuses on strengthening and expanding the power grid network, which is essential for energy transmission but does not directly specify the type of energy being transmitted

title: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation donated blankets and winter clothes of unknown value to Dulalpur Village, Bangladesh
description: On December 18, 2020, China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation Bangladesh Limited donated a batch of blankets and winter clothes to Dulalpur Village in Brahmanpara Upazila, Cumilla. The aid was distributed to over 2,000 disadvantaged villagers during the COVID-19 pandemic and was a part of the company's 2020 Winter Relief Programme, a corporate responsibility initiative. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation donated blankets and winter clothes of unknown value to Dulalpur Village, Bangladesh

# Description
On December 18, 2020, China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation Bangladesh Limited donated a batch of blankets and winter clothes to Dulalpur Village in Brahmanpara Upazila, Cumilla. The aid was distributed to over 2,000 disadvantaged villagers during the COVID-19 pandemic and was a part of the company's 2020 Winter Relief Programme, a corporate responsibility initiative. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a humanitarian aid initiative with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of blankets and winter clothes to disadvantaged villagers, part of corporate responsibility initiative

title: China donates emergency medical supplies to Bangladesh for COVID-19 relief in March 2020
description: On March 26, 2020, the Chinese government donated emergency medical supplies to the government of Bangladesh. The donation consisted of 15,000 surgical masks, 10,000 COVID-19 test kits, 10,000 items of personal protective equipment (PPE), and 1,000 thermometers. The purpose of the donation was to assist Bangladesh in its fight against COVID-19. The Bangladeshi Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the Bangladeshi Ministry of Foreign Affairs were present to receive the donation. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.

title: National Health Commission of China sends medical team to Bangladesh to aid in COVID-19 relief efforts
description: On June 8, 2020, a team of ten medical professionals sent by the National Health Commission of China arrived in Dhaka, Bangladesh. These professionals were respiratory physicians experienced in treating and handling COVID-19. They visited hospitals, testing centers, and quarantine centers in Dhaka to assist in treating patients and collaborated with Bangladeshi professionals to develop a plan to contain the pandemic. As of June 21, 2020, the team had visited 11 medical institutions, held 41 meetings, held 13 training sessions for 599 trainees (an additional 5,000 people watched online), provided technical guidance for 13 times, and accepted 5 media interviews. They returned to China on June 22, 2020.

These professionals were respiratory physicians experienced in treating and handling COVID-19. They visited hospitals, testing centers, and quarantine centers in Dhaka to assist in treating patients and collaborated with Bangladeshi professionals to develop a plan to contain the pandemic. As of June 21, 2020, the team had visited 11 medical institutions, held 41 meetings, held 13 training sessions for 599 trainees (an additional 5,000 people watched online), provided technical guidance for 13 times, and accepted 5 media interviews. They returned to China on June 22, 2020.

evidence: Medical team deployment, COVID-19 relief efforts, training sessions, technical guidance

title: PowerChina Chengdu Engineering Corp Ltd. donates medical supplies to Dhaka Water Supply and Sewage Authority in Bangladesh for COVID-19 protection
description: On April 6, 2020, PowerChina Chengdu Engineering Corp Ltd. donated medical supplies, including 30,000 surgical face masks, 3,000 KN90 face masks, and 545 sets of protective suits, thermometer guns and goggles to Dhaka Water Supply and Sewage Authority (DWASA). The purpose of this donation was to aid DWASA in providing necessary protection against the spread of COVID-19, as they were in dire need of PPE. Tazur Islam, Minister of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives of Bangladesh, and relevant government departments witnessed the donation. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
